title: How to Take Softwood Cuttings

steps.headline: Take your cuttings in the morning during late spring.
steps.description: New growths produce roots better than hardened stems, so plan on removing the cuttings before the summer growing season. Avoid taking your cutting during the day or in the evening since the plant will grow during the day and use up a lot of its energy. Wait until the early morning so the plant can recover overnight. By definition, softwood cuttings are only taken from new growths. Otherwise, they would be considered hardwood cuttings.

steps.headline: Choose new growths that are 4–6 in (10–15 cm) for your cuttings.
steps.description: Pick growths near the top of your plant rather than the bottom since they tend to be healthier. Look for fresh shoots that are at least 4 inches (10 cm) branching off from the sides of a larger stem. Search for 3–4 stems that are disease- and damage-free so you have better chances of one taking root. Some of the easiest shrubs to propagate include lilac, weigela, forsythia, lavender, salvia, barberry, and potentilla. You can try any plant that produces shoots sideways out from its stems. Shrubs that are old or have been heavily fertilized may not propagate as well as newer plants.

steps.headline: Cut the growths off of the plant just below a leaf with a pair of hand pruners.
steps.description: Place your pruners at a 45-degree angle so it’s directly underneath at least 1 leaf on the stem. Squeeze the handles of the pruners together to cut through the stem. Continue removing the rest of the cuttings from the plant until you have as many as you want to plant. Never remove more than a third of the plant’s foliage, or else it may not survive as well.Tip: If you’re taking cuttings from multiple plants, clean the pruners with a cotton ball and rubbing alcohol after you take each cutting to prevent the spread of disease.

steps.headline: Pinch off the leaves from the lower halves of the cuttings.
steps.description: Grab the leaves as close to the base as you can and gently pull them off. Only remove the leaves from the bottom half of the cutting, or else it won’t be able to get as much light to grow roots. Repeat the process when any other cuttings you’ve taken so you can easily plant them later on. If your cuttings have flowers near the tops of the stems, pinch them off as well. If you’re worried about damaging the stem, you can also cut the leaves off with a sharp knife. Be sure to disinfect the blade with rubbing alcohol if you’re trimming multiple plants.

steps.headline: Cut the remaining leaves in half to help the cuttings root better.
steps.description: Leaves take moisture out of the soil and can prevent healthy root growth when your cuttings propagate. Lay the leaves flat against a cutting surface and slice the leaves in half so the cut is perpendicular to the leaves’ central veins. Continue halving the rest of the leaves on the cutting. You do not need to cut the leaves in half if you don’t want to. Keep the cuttings inside of a plastic bag in your fridge if you aren’t planting them right away. Try to plant them within 1–2 days so they don’t lose moisture.

steps.headline: Fill a pot that has drainage holes with equal parts of compost and sand.
steps.description: Get a pot that is 7 inches (18 cm) wide and 7 inches (18 cm) deep for your cuttings. Make sure there are drainage holes on the bottom of the pot so the growing medium doesn’t get too waterlogged. Thoroughly combine 1 part natural compost along with 1 part coarse horticultural sand and use it to fill the pot. Leave 1 inch (2.5 cm) of space between the top of the mix and the rim so water doesn’t spill out. You can buy compost and horticultural sand from your local gardening center. You can also use planting trays if you plan on propagating multiple cuttings at the same time.

steps.headline: Water the compost mixture to dampen the soil before planting.
steps.description: Use a watering can to slowly pour the water into the pot. Continue adding water until it puddles on top of the compost before stopping. Let the water seep into the soil and drain out the bottom so it’s moist all the way throughout the pot. Once the water drains the first time, pour the water until it starts puddling again and let it drain a second time. Feel the compost mixture 2 inches (5.1 cm) down with your finger to see if it feels wet. If it’s not moist, then try watering again. Otherwise, you’re ready to plant in it.

steps.headline: Poke holes that are 2 in (5.1 cm) deep into the growing medium.
steps.description: Stick the end of the pencil into the compost mixture to start your hole. Wiggle the pencil around to widen the hole so the diameter is slightly wider than the diameter of the cutting you’re planting. Space additional holes so they’re about 4 inches (10 cm) apart do your cuttings have room to form their roots without competing for nutrients. You can also make the holes with your fingers if you want.

steps.headline: Dip the cut ends of the stems in rooting hormone powder.
steps.description: Pour some of the rooting hormone powder into a small dish so you’re able to put the ends of the cuttings in it. Place the last ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of the cut end into the rooting hormone powder and coat it completely. Shake any excess powder back into the dish and set the cutting aside. Repeat the process with the other cuttings so they’re more likely to grow. You can buy rooting hormone powder from your local gardening store.Tip: Throw out any leftover rooting hormone powder rather than putting it back in the original container. That way, you can prevent contamination or disease later on.

steps.headline: Place the cut ends into the holes and firm up the compost around them.
steps.description: Put the cuttings into their holes one at a time so they’re easier to work with. Set the cut end into the hole so the cutting stands up vertically. Compact the compost mixture so it forms a small hill around the base of the cutting to prevent it from tipping over. Continue planting the rest of your cuttings in the pot. Don’t let the compost mixture touch the leaves since you could cause your propagations to develop rot.

steps.headline: Cover the pot with a plastic bag and rubber band to trap humidity.
steps.description: Use a clear plastic bag that’s large enough to fit around the rim of the pot and contain the cuttings without touching them. Slide the bag over the edge of the pot and seal it with a rubber band to help keep the moisture and humidity inside the container. Make sure the bag doesn’t touch any of the leaves, or else moisture could get on them and develop rot. You can use an old grocery bag or even a milk jug for your cover as well.Tip: If the plastic bag touches your cuttings, poke wooden stakes that are taller than the cuttings around the edge of the pot before putting the plastic bag over it.

steps.headline: Set the pot in an area with bright light out of direct sun.
steps.description: Keep the pot somewhere indoors, such as a south-facing window, or in a spot outside that has light shade throughout the day. Store the pot there through the entire rooting process to ensure that the plant gets enough light and nutrients. Leave the bag on the pot while the cuttings take root so the heat gets trapped inside and warms the compost mixture. You may also use a growing light for your cuttings if you’re keeping them indoors. Avoid direct sunlight since it could cause the foliage to grow more than the roots and make your plants unhealthy.

steps.headline: Mist the growing medium if it starts drying out.
steps.description: Feel the surface of the compost mixture with your finger every 2–3 days to see if it’s dry to the touch. If it still feels moist, leave the cuttings alone so they don’t get overwatered. If the surface feels dry or grainy, fill a spray bottle with clean water and mist the compost mixture until it’s damp again. Try to use purified water if you’re able to so your cuttings don’t get any contamination. You can also use your watering can if you don’t have a spray bottle available.

steps.headline: Remove the plastic bag after 6–8 weeks to harden off the plants.
steps.description: After 6–8 weeks, your cuttings will have established roots of their own and are ready to be exposed to open air. Pull off the plastic bag and leave the cuttings in the same spot. Water and care for the plants as you normally would so they continue growing. Hardening off gets the cuttings used to a growing environment so they aren’t stressed when they’re transplanted. If the leaves on your cuttings wilt, they may not grow well when you transplant them.

steps.headline: Transplant the cuttings to separate containers 3–4 days after taking off the bag.
steps.description: Carefully dig around the base of each cutting to free up the roots. Choose pots that are at least twice as wide and twice as deep as the root systems for your cuttings, and fill them halfway with equal parts compost and coarse sand. Lift the cuttings by their roots and set them in their own pots. Fill in the rest of the compost mixture around the plant so the cuttings can continue growing. Don’t transplant the cuttings directly into the ground since they may not successfully grow. Try to keep the cuttings in their pots until the next spring when the plants are more established.
